text:

name: sfchronicle
text: For this week's Throughline, we looked at the ways we use technology, and how it can change in a world with coronavirus ‚Äî for better or for worse. https://t.co/l7WiyZnPcf

name: sfchronicle
text:
The pandemic has cast a spotlight on San Francisco‚Äôs glaring digital divide. How do we close it? 

Bay Area tech, activists and @GregRThomas have some ideas, starting with making the internet public: https://t.co/vvBvkitMpi

name: sfchronicle
text: The old-school burrito shop is under threat from delivery apps, with the pandemic accelerating the process. @PeterHartlaub shines a spotlight on the choices we make that may shape the future of small businesses. https://t.co/vVgmn0LcE8

name: sfchronicle
text: From a coronavirus radar scan to personal air filters, here are some pandemic-fighting tech ideas ‚Äî and how realistic they are, according to Bay Area futurist @psaffo: https://t.co/pe5A20PfSV https://t.co/FU6APalahL

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúPursuing a thought, even for a minute, is increasingly hard.‚Äù Stanford professor Byron Reeves shares with @samwhitingsf how smartphones may affect our attention spans, relationships and the 2020 election.  https://t.co/PYJPcKDO88

text: .@EmilyDreyfuss imagines a day in 2022: ‚ÄúZoom shirts,‚Äù remote theater and endless video conferences: https://t.co/VtxXtsG3de

name: sfchronicle
text:
Gov. Newsom says California cannot participate in the plan President Trump has proposed to offer a $400 expanded weekly unemployment benefit. The proposal would cost California $700 million per week to fund its 25% share.
https://t.co/RwYg9K9IJB

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúForgive me for being human,‚Äù Gov. Newsom said, after a reporter asked for details on the resignation of Dr. Sonia Angell, the state‚Äôs health officer.
